Text: For the choirmaster. Of the Sons of Korah. According to Alamoth. A song.
Context: This is the title of the Psalm and gives instructions for its musical and liturgical use. The Sons of Korah were a family of temple singers; "Alamoth" refers to the musical setting, possibly a high pitch or the voices of virgins.

Text: God is our refuge and strength, an ever-present help in trouble.
Context: The verse expresses a strong confidence in God as protector and source of strength when faced with distress.

Text: Therefore we will not fear, though the earth is transformed and the mountains are toppled into the depths of the sea,
Context: This verse continues the theme of confidence from the previous verse, despite catastrophic events in nature.

Text: though its waters roar and foam and the mountains quake in the surging sea. Selah
Context: The mention of roaring waters and quaking mountains could evoke awe or fear, but the overall tone remains neutral within the context of trust in God’s protection. "Selah" is likely a musical pause or interlude.

Text: There is a river whose streams delight the city of God, the holy place where the Most High dwells.
Context: In contrast to the previous tumultuous images, this verse introduces calming imagery of a river symbolizing God’s provision and peace for Jerusalem, His holy city.

Text: God is within her; she will not be moved. God will help her when morning dawns.
Context: This verse reinforces the idea that God's presence in the city ensures its stability and that He will offer timely aid.

Text: The nations rage, the kingdoms totter; He lifts His voice, the earth melts.
Context: The verse contrasts the raging of nations and instability of earthly kingdoms with the power of God’s voice to dissolve earthly conflicts and exert control.

Text: The LORD of Hosts is with us; the God of Jacob is our fortress. Selah
Context: This verse affirms God's presence and protection, using military imagery of a fortress to depict security. "Selah" may indicate another pause for reflection.

Text: Come, see the works of the LORD, the desolations He has brought on the earth.
Context: Calling for observation of God's mighty deeds which can lead to desolation as a demonstration of His power over the earth.

Text: He makes wars to cease to the end of the earth; He breaks the bow and shatters the spear; He burns the shields with fire.
Context: This verse illustrates God’s power to bring peace by ending wars and destroying weapons.

Text: Be still and know that I am God; I will be exalted among the nations, I will be exalted in the earth. A call for calm and recognition of God’s sovereignty, with an affirmation of His exalted status universally recognized.
The LORD of Hosts is with us; the God of Jacob is our fortress.
Context: This verse is a repeat of verse 7, emphasizing God's enduring presence and protection as a continual source of trust.
